Evaluation_Questions: Your level of engagement with the course was
What is your overall assessment of this course
The course was well organized to facilitate student learning
I received clear feedback that improved my learning
Relative to other courses you have taken at Yale, the level of <u>intellectual challenge</u> of this course was
Relative to other courses you have taken at Yale, the <u>workload</u> of this course was
Comments_Questions: What knowledge, skills, and insights did you develop by taking this course
What are the strengths and weaknesses of this course and how could it be improved
Would you recommend this course to another student? Please explain
Comments_List: How to write a logical specific aims page!

Knowledge-
Learned about specific topics in fields of Pharm, Phys and Path. miRNA in sperm development, heat sensing ion channels, crystallography based approaches, KRAS/RAF protein signalling, etc. 
Skills-
How to research background on a project. Slight experiment design thinking.How to write specific aims for grant proposals.
Insights-
The proportion of proposal space that should be allocated to each section.
This course was fantastic. I developed more technical writing skills and critical evaluation of the literature. I gained more experience presenting and sharing my thoughts in a group setting.
Grantsmanship, reading papers
I learned a lot about the structure and composition of a formal grant proposal. I also gained experience in identifying new potential projects based on completed research.
I learned the proper structure of a specific aim through his critiques of my writing.
I learned how to write better.
I was able to develop a lot of my writing skills, in addition to improving my ability to critically read papers and come up with "next step" experiments.
Definitely the most instructive course I took this semester. It developed my scientific writing skills far beyond what I would have expected for a semester of work.
How to write a proposal
writing skills about proposal; insights of various biomedical topics.
This course is excellent at giving you a survey of different fields, but doesn't seem to have a cohesive vision for what is to be learned.

Strengths-
There is a huge benefit through this course in terms of learning how to approach research questions in different fields and construct a viable research proposal
Weaknesses- 
It is a huge time commitment. Given that it is a year-long endeavour, the benefit of writing these assignments probably does not increase with increasing iterations of the same exercise. Maybe a rotation with another kind of exercise might be beneficial.

The strengths were the content and professors engagements, the weaknesses were really just style the second half of the course going around the table and having each student talk. More round table rapid fire talking would be better.

Strength: Very good to learn to read and write grants; high engagement in a variety of science topics

Weakness: Perhaps too much focus on cancer biology?
The instructors were always very helpful in clarifying questions about the papers, however the round table style of reading our proposals did not feel as productive as it could have been.

I think the way it's run now is ideal. It can be difficult to participate in free discussion considering the size of our cohort and the time constraints. By having us discuss our specific aims, we avoid that issue.
It can be really difficult to keep up with this during normal classes, but it was really interesting.
I would appreciate more detailed feedback about writing style and a better understanding about each section of the specific aims.

Would be nice if the off-weeks were more consistent; maybe hard due to scheduling with the guest faculty

Would be good to get more detailed feedbacks. Sometimes, "good" "great" and "ok" are the only comments i receive on the SA. Just a sentence or phase afterwards would be much more helpful for the next SA.

I loved having to write a new proposal every week. While it was awful in the moment, looking back it helped me develop my writing and critical thinking abilities a lot. I would like to have a bit more of a focus on methods, especially as someone who has never used cellular methods in the past. I felt a little bit like I was in over my head at certain points, because a lot of methods that were assumed to be widely understood by everyone were completely unfamiliar to me.
I think this course is everything it needs to be.  My biggest complaint all through the semester was that the class made me think, which is of course exactly what classes are supposed to do.
I can receive feedbacks every week. Its great.

Strengths: Motivates us to think about research and think about how to start a research project. Feedbacks. Discussions. 

Weaknesses: workload is a little heavy. some topics are not interesting to me.
Not necessarily.
Absolutely, although a lot of work, the benefits of this course are obvious.
Yes, I would recommend all first year PhD students take this course.
Yes!
I would recommend this course because it helps you hone a valuable skill that will be important further down the road as we apply for future grants.

Yes. It was challenging, which led me to appreciate it a lot more than standard lecture classes. I felt engaged and it was required that I actively participate in my own learning, which helped significantly and improved my enjoyment of the course.
Yes. It's an essential for a first year graduate student in the program, and unlike other requirements, will show clear benefit.
Yes. Knowing how to write a proposal is very important for PhD student.
It depends. If the student would like to practice his/her academic writing and he/she is interested in physiological, pathological research, I will recommend this one to him/her.
